captions.text: Good morning, Hank, it's Tuesday.

Bonus video time! So while I was in Ethiopia,
I filmed several videos where I talked to

Bill Gates about stuff. In this one, we talk
about healthcare.

I'm gonna be uploading these every Tuesday
for the next month or so - a couple hours

before my regular Vlogbrothers video, so enjoy
the bonus! And, you know.. the Bill Gates.

John: I'm wondering if you could just kind
of talk me through what you just saw and what

your questions were, and what you find encouraging
about that, and, and any concerns that you
have?

Bill: These primary healthcare facilities
are how we've taken childhood death down from

about 25% of all children to now about 5%.
Getting the vaccines out so that every child

gets all these vaccines, that's really hard,
they have to be kept cold, and of course,

most poor kids live in very rural areas, where
there's not very good roads, not many trained

workers. So Ethiopia created this system where
at the lowest level, there's a health-post,

and here, we're at this health center. Some
of the regions, particularly where people

are pastoral and move around a lot, that's
still where they have less than 30% vaccination

rates. The rest of the country is up at about
75%, and there's a plan to get it up to 90%.

John: So can you talk about a little bit about
how, how we know that the reduction in infant

mortality is related to this dramatic improvement
in sort of last mile healthcare delivery?

Bill: The statistics from poor countries are
often very poor. The one statistic that's

really good is the number of children who
die. Tragically, in a lot of countries, uh,

that was very very high, and because it was
a limited number of infectious diseases, by

getting the right vaccines to these poor countries,
we've cut those death rates down a lot. Another

huge tragedy beyond death, is that even the
kids who survive don't physically or mentally

fully develop, and there you've got to lower
the burden of the disease a lot. You've got

to get good sanitation, and you've got to
get good food. Now, the other thing about

health is that as more children survive, amazingly,
mothers choose to have less children. And

so, the whole population growth challenge,
which is: Can I feed? Can I educate? Can I

provide jobs? That becomes more achievable,
and then you get out of the poverty trap.

And so, health is not the only thing, but
it is, in my view, the central thing, the

thing you really have, you have to get that
right, or else the country will not be able

to, uh, keep its children alive and support
itself.

title: Bill Gates and John Green Discuss Global Health

comments.text:
John, you should write a book where a autistic child is portrayed as being 
able to feel all the same emotions that everyone one else is. I have 
Asperger's syndrome, an autism spectrum disorder, I hate how people with 
autism spectrum disorders are portrayed as being emotionless, never being 
shown as able to love and be loved. I can say, if anyone can, that this is 
just so wrong, I've battled depression, I've been bullied by both students 
and teachers, I have felt all the things teenagers feel, but people don't 
see people with autism this way, simply because they don't express these 
emotions through the same body language and facial expressions that other 
people do. Although I have largely learned how to make eye contact and read 
body language and all those things I am fairly certain other people can 
tell something is different about me. You seem like someone who would write 
a book like this, after reading the fault in our stars I wouldn't be 
surprised is you did write something like this.﻿

comments.author: 101qwertyqwertyful

comments.text:
These videos are tough for me to watch because I have such mix feelings 
about Bill Gates.  I'm grateful that the Gates Foundation is doing this 
work.  A large scale investment in the poverty stricken areas of the world 
is so long overdue that it's a travesty.   However, there are millions of 
professionals working for non-profits around the world who have also 
decided to make the world a better place.  In the US alone there are 
roughly 600,000 social workers like myself.  We shoulder the largest share 
of the professional burden, while garnering the least professional respect 
and commanding the lowest salaries.  Just like Bill Gates, we decided to 
try and make an impact on the problems of the world around us.  However, 
prior to the formation of the Gates Foundation, Bill Gates spent 35 years 
building an empire through ruthless business practices that rival those of 
the great robber barons.  He gets put on the cover of Time Magazine.  We 
get to worry about our 401(k)'s.  It's frustrating. ﻿
comments.author: Thom Simonson

comments.text:
I was sent this TED talk the other week in a YouTube comment section (I 
believe on CGP Grey's recent video "Human's need not apply" [watch that if 
you haven't seen that already, it's well worth your time!]), and it really 
highlights what Bill Gates is talking about here. It shows how child 
mortality rate decreasing is the key to a country's economy growing, the 
quality of life improving and the population of the country becoming lower. 
If you're interested in this it will be an enlightening 10 minutes
https://www.ted.com/talks/hans_rosling_on_global_population_growth﻿

comments.author: INBCPC1994

comments.text:
So, the poverty trap and Ethiopia.  Dropping child mortality seems to be 
working, good.  This poverty trap makes things some much more complex.  A 
friend just called me from Bethesda, MD who says he knew you from a long 
time ago.  Net worth around $100 m.  He said Carnegie said it's harder to 
give money than to make it.  I suppose an interjection of carefully given 
added would be helpful.  There are lots of ways to end the poverty trap but 
what is the best way?  For some reason I am fixated on brick and mortar 
today.  I think it has to do with improving the earthen floor.

At the dawn of my salad days or Jane's ancient history I was interning for 
a city planning position.  At the same areawide planning center, a 5 county 
area in the South, was a historic preservationist.  Our earlier Americans 
did not go down to Home Depot to buy Quick Create, or ask Guido, the cement 
mixer how to make building products.  They used what was around.......which 
thankfully did not often mean cow paddies.  Can't they, Ethiopians, do some 
sort of early stage building product creation that employs good sanitation 
techniques and materials?﻿

comments.author: booknerdbooknerd

comments.text:
Bill Gates means well, but he recently put out some damaging misinformation 
- suggesting that we should work to power the third world with fossil 
fuels, and leave the clean energy innovation to the first world:

http://www.gatesnotes.com/Energy/Two-Videos-Illuminate-Energy-Poverty-Bjorn-Lomborg

The reality is that clean energy is now cost competitive with fossil fuels 
even in the first world. Our utilities are struggling to convince 
regulators they're the only real answer to energy problems, but they're 
losing ground every day.

It's quite a complex subject, but Gates really dropped the ball here by not 
considering the latest data. His assumptions are fundamentally wrong. The 
last thing the third world needs is large centralized power generators and 
massive transmission infrastructure.

Distributed wind, solar and geothermal will save money, be more reliable, 
and doesn't unwittingly commit regions to 50 years of burning fossil fuels 
in order to meet their needs.

Elon will tell you what's up in the energy industry these days. By 
perpetuating these myths you're hurting entrepreneurs already battling 
immensely powerful incumbent energy providers. Do your research before you 
publish your musings on your blog Bill!﻿
